articles.headline: Same-Sex Marriage Rights Bill Clears a Crucial Senate Hurdle
articles.snippet: Democrats made the same-sex marriage bill one of their first major agenda items in the postelection session, moving quickly to enact it while their party still controls both chambers.
articles.abstract: Democrats made the same-sex marriage bill one of their first major agenda items in the postelection session, moving quickly to enact it while their party still controls both chambers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Wednesday took a crucial step toward passing landmark legislation to provide federal protections for same-sex marriages, as 12 Republicans joined Democrats to advance the Respect for Marriage Act, putting it on track to become law in the twilight of the Democratic-held Congress.

articles.headline: U.S. Shoppers Are Still Spending, as Long as Retailers Give Them a Reasons To
articles.snippet: Retail sales rose last month, and several companies reported strong earnings. But discounts seemed to drive a significant portion of purchases.
articles.abstract: Retail sales rose last month, and several companies reported strong earnings. But discounts seemed to drive a significant portion of purchases.
articles.lead_paragraph: Despite months of unease about the state of the economy, Americans remain willing to spend money on all sorts of goods. But they are making it clear that retailers must work harder than they have over the past two years to win their dollars.

articles.headline: Republicans capture control of the House after falling short of midterm expectations.
articles.snippet: After more than a week of counting, the Republican Party gained the 218 House seats needed to claim the majority, ushering in an era of divided government.
articles.abstract: After more than a week of counting, the Republican Party gained the 218 House seats needed to claim the majority, ushering in an era of divided government.
articles.lead_paragraph: Republicans secured a slender majority in the House of Representatives on Wednesday, a delayed yet consequential finish to the 2022 midterm elections that will reorder the balance of power in Washington and is expected to effectively give the party a veto on President Biden’s agenda for the next two years.

articles.headline: ‘This Is Not Ukraine’s Fault’: Tensions Ease Over Missile Strike in Poland
articles.snippet: NATO and Polish officials said that it was a Ukrainian missile that crossed the border and killed two people, but that Russia bore the blame.
articles.abstract: NATO and Polish officials said that it was a Ukrainian missile that crossed the border and killed two people, but that Russia bore the blame.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — A top NATO official and Poland’s president said on Wednesday that a Ukrainian air-defense missile, not a Russian weapon, had most likely caused a deadly explosion on Polish territory, easing fears that the military alliance would become more deeply embroiled in the war.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Marc Santora

articles.headline: Key Allies Are Inching Away From Trump
articles.snippet: Early signs suggest he may struggle to win over Republican Party leaders for his third presidential bid, after a string of disappointments, but Donald Trump’s staunchest voters are another matter.
articles.abstract: Early signs suggest he may struggle to win over Republican Party leaders for his third presidential bid, after a string of disappointments, but Donald Trump’s staunchest voters are another matter.
articles.lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Three billionaire donors have moved on and others are actively weighing their options. A number of former allies are staying on the sidelines. A long list of potential rivals — from popular governors to members of Congress — are seriously assessing their chances for 2024. Even his own daughter has declined to get involved.
articles.byline: By Reid J. Epstein, Lisa Lerer and Jonathan Weisman

articles.headline: A New Source of Economic Anxiety in Britain: Soaring Mortgage Rates
articles.snippet: After more than a decade of ultralow interest rates, millions of British households suddenly face large jumps in their monthly payments, rocking the nation’s already weak economy.
articles.abstract: After more than a decade of ultralow interest rates, millions of British households suddenly face large jumps in their monthly payments, rocking the nation’s already weak economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: In June 2021, Monique Foulger reached a major milestone: At 30 years old, she bought her first home, a modest one-bedroom flat in Croydon in South London.

articles.headline: SpaceX Employees Say They Were Fired for Speaking Up About Elon Musk
articles.snippet: Charges filed with federal regulators accuse the company of retaliating against eight workers over an open letter critical of the chief executive.
articles.abstract: Charges filed with federal regulators accuse the company of retaliating against eight workers over an open letter critical of the chief executive.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By Noam Scheiber and Ryan Mac

articles.headline: Why Office Buildings Are Still in Trouble
articles.snippet: Hybrid work, layoffs and higher interest rates are leaving lots of office space vacant and hurting the commercial real estate business.
articles.abstract: Hybrid work, layoffs and higher interest rates are leaving lots of office space vacant and hurting the commercial real estate business.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the pandemic receding, children back in school and businesses telling employees to return to the office, the companies that own big office buildings were hoping to move on this fall from a nightmarish two years.
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis, Julie Creswell and Joe Rennison

articles.headline: Meet Your New Corporate Office Mate: A ‘Brainless’ Robot
articles.snippet: Naver, a South Korean internet firm, is trying to introduce robots into the world of cubicles and conference rooms without making employees uncomfortable.
articles.abstract: Naver, a South Korean internet firm, is trying to introduce robots into the world of cubicles and conference rooms without making employees uncomfortable.
articles.lead_paragraph: The new workers zipped around the office completing mundane tasks like fetching coffee, delivering meals and handing off packages. They did not get in anyone’s way or violate personal space. They waited unobtrusively for elevators with unfailing politeness. And, perhaps most enticingly, they did not complain.
articles.byline: By John Yoon and Daisuke Wakabayashi

articles.headline: New Chief Calls FTX’s Corporate Control a ‘Complete Failure’
articles.snippet: “This situation is unprecedented,” said John J. Ray III, who helped manage Enron after its collapse in an accounting fraud scandal in 2001.
articles.abstract: “This situation is unprecedented,” said John J. Ray III, who helped manage Enron after its collapse in an accounting fraud scandal in 2001.
articles.lead_paragraph: John Jay Ray III helped manage the aftermath of some of the largest corporate failures in history, including the implosion of the energy trading firm Enron after an accounting fraud scandal in 2001.

articles.headline: Pelosi Steps Aside, Signaling End to Historic Run as Top House Democrat
articles.snippet: “For me, the hour has come for a new generation to lead the Democratic caucus that I so deeply respect,” Speaker Nancy Pelosi said. She has led her party in the House for two decades.
articles.abstract: “For me, the hour has come for a new generation to lead the Democratic caucus that I so deeply respect,” Speaker Nancy Pelosi said. She has led her party in the House for two decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow the latest news on Nancy Pelosi stepping down from leadership.

articles.headline: Police Expected the Halloween Crowd. Why Couldn’t They Stop the Disaster?
articles.snippet: An analysis, based on official documents and parliamentary testimony, reveals that authorities in South Korea missed crucial chances to prevent a crowd crush that would kill 158 people.
articles.abstract: An analysis, based on official documents and parliamentary testimony, reveals that authorities in South Korea missed crucial chances to prevent a crowd crush that would kill 158 people.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, officials had known that Halloween weekends in Itaewon, a popular nightlife district in Seoul, attracted large crowds, warning internally that people could be “crushed to death.”

articles.headline: Elizabeth Holmes’s Fraud Sentence Will Send a Message One Way or Another
articles.snippet: Ms. Holmes, founder of the failed blood testing start-up Theranos, is scheduled to learn her fate on Friday. She faces a maximum of 20 years in prison.
articles.abstract: Ms. Holmes, founder of the failed blood testing start-up Theranos, is scheduled to learn her fate on Friday. She faces a maximum of 20 years in prison.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Elizabeth Holmes was sentenced to more than 11 years in prison. Follow for the latest news.]
